intro: Cuphea antisyphilitica var. acutifolia, commonly known as the spiked cuphea, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of the Americas. It is characterized by its narrow, lance-shaped leaves and striking spikes of tubular, brightly colored flowers. The plant typically grows as an upright shrub, reaching heights of up to 3 feet, and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its flowers, which come in shades of red, orange, and yellow, attract pollinators such as bees and hummingbirds. The species is valued in horticulture for its ornamental appeal and ability to thrive in well-drained soil.
